bannerText:
One day in 1987, Frank had an idea: compose an album's worth of drum parts, then hand them over as the foundation of music to be subsequently produced. We did not discuss style or structure. It simply had to incorporate 42 minutes of manic drum parts.

Incidentally, the drum parts were hand-written as around 50 pages of drum sheets. Frank then tapped these parts into a Roland TR-505 drum box. Crazy.

This music was produced on the venerable Tascam 22-4; three tracks of live instruments plus an FSK sync track. On the live tracks were all the guitars, some real bass guitar, a few live keys, and some noises. The FSK track provided MIDI sync, driving the TR-505 and a Yamaha QX-5, a hardware sequencer containing MIDI data for most of the keyboard parts.
